Primary sludge and secondary sludge will be thickened in the sludge storage/thickener tank. While improving the quality of the water, urban sewage plants have brought problems to its surrounding environment, the most typical of which is the problem of odor pollution. The Al Khansa WWTP uses oxidation ditches typical for conventional treatment plant design that emits unacceptable odors during operation especially next to the Medical City Complex in the center of the capital Baghdad and very close to the Tigris River that could be developed in the future to a park.  Al Khansa WWTP was designed to use conventional Aeration Chambers for treatment.  These chambers are open surface tanks that agitate the sewage water as it passes through it with rotating brushes. Odor control for the Medical  City / Al Zuyut Vertical Treatment Plants will be provided by enclosing the headworks and sludge dewatering equipment in the headworks building.  Shaft 1 will also be covered.  Fresh air for these enclosed areas will be provided and form the input to the activated sludge aeration compressors.  This will result in the odors emanating from these enclosed portions of the plant to be deodorized by the mixed liquor. 
Odor is one of the negative impacts of any wastewater treatment facility and especially in congested areas like the Medical Center area.  Because of the compact nature of the Treatment Shaft and the facility is not spread out and limited to only a few structures, providing cover for the facility is an effective way of controlling odor emission.  Air ventilation from the space below the cover will reduce odor escaping outside.  Exhaust air will be directed to the air blower for the aeration chamber for treatment.
